discussion.content: Packet tracer supports "transport input all", does not support "transport input telnet ssh".

comments.content:
SW4(config-line)#transport input ssh telnet
 ^
% Invalid input detected at '^' marker.
 
SW4(config-line)#

Actual routers and switches accept the "transport input telnet ssh" command.
Also, this is stated in the official cert guide.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
If you set transport input telnet, it will override any previous config. So, in real device you should set transport input telnet ssh, if you want both. In Packet Tracer this is not allowed, instead it is transport input all.

Router(config-line)#transport input ssh

% Invalid input detected at '^' marker.


Router(config-line)#transport input all
Router(config-line)#
Packet Tracer is simply just good enough to learn most material, and not meant to replicate all commands of Cisco hardware, hence this situation is definitely an example!
transport input telnet ssh

questions.question_text: Which command can you enter to allow Telnet to be supported in addition to SSH?

choices.A: Configure the dns server on the same subnet as the clients

discussion.content:
Answer is correct, since question is "Which action is most likely to correct the problem?"
Means that the given set of command is missing something. 

Since when we are configuring a DHCP server on a router:

conf t
service dhcp
ip dhcp pool <pool name>
network <network address of the pool>
default-router <ip address of the interface facing the hosts, or ip adress of the interface facing downstream clients>
dns-server <ip address of dns-server>
exit

comments.content: This is to configure it directly on the equipment. We want the DHCP server to send the information to it.
Be careful, To define a default gateway (router) when IP routing is disabled, use the ip default-gateway global configuration command.
This is different to DHCP configuration.

Is not configuring the default gate this command?:
SW1(config)# ip default-gateway 192.168.10.1

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct
in DHCP we need to configure..
1. Network
2. Default Gateway
3. DNS

comments.content:
The network command from within DHCP configuration mode accepts a prefix-length directly as an argument, as an alternative to a netmask.

The command is in the form "network network-number [mask | /prefix-length] [secondary]".

See https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/ipaddr_dhcp/configuration/15-sy/dhcp-15-sy-book/config-dhcp-server.html

discussion.content: why not C? i am a beginner, but I also know that you should put the "subnet mask" not the "/27", wouldnt it become and error?
THE (DHCP#) DEFAULT-ROUTER IS MISSING FROM THE EXHIBIT
D. Configure the default gateway

comments.content: Correct, you can't input a subnet mask in CIDR notation as shown in this question.

discussion.content: I know the answer is D, but we can't put de mask for network in CIDR right?

comments.content: The DNS sever does not need to be on the same subnet as your clients. You can double check this by going into your network settings and adjusting DNS to 1.1.1.1 or 8.8.8.8. You can check the before and after results with ipconfig /all in command prompt. Typically your default DNS server on your local network is your default gateway on SOHO routers but your SOHO router will send that DNS query up to the ISP and typically one of their DNS servers will answer your DNS query. Remember your router is typically getting DHCP information from the ISP as well.
It's possible, but without more information you'd have to make an assumption whereas, with D there is clearly a default gateway missing.

discussion.content: D is more right but arguably A could be right too

questions.answer_description: An address conflict occurs when two hosts use the same IP address. During address assignment, DHCP checks for conflicts using ping and gratuitous ARP. If a conflict is detected, the address is removed from the pool. The address will not be assigned until the administrator resolves the conflict.

choices.D: Only the IP detected by Ping is removed from the pool.
choices.A: The address is removed from the pool until the conflict is resolved.
choices.E: The IP will be shown, even after the conflict is resolved.
choices.B: The address remains in the pool until the conflict is resolved.
choices.C: Only the IP detected by Gratuitous ARP is removed from the pool.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit. Which rule does the DHCP server use when there is an IP address conflict?
//IMG//

discussion.content: Didn't know we had routers in 1198 lol

When the DHCP server detects there is a conflict of an IP address before or right after it is assigned to a client, it will automatically remove the IP address from the DHCP pool and move it to the DHCP conflict table. The IP address in question will remain there until an administrator sees and clears the DHCP conflict table.

https://www.firewall.cx/cisco-technical-knowledgebase/cisco-switches/1063-cisco-switch-router-dhcp-server-conflicts.html

Selected Answer: A
A is correct
I think A is correct, the address is removed from the pool.
A. The address is removed from the pool until the conflict is resolved.

questions.question_text: Which command can you enter to determine the addresses that have been assigned on a DHCP Server?

discussion.content:
Seems Correct answer is B
Switch#sh ip dhcp ?
 binding DHCP address bindings
 conflict DHCP address conflicts
 pool DHCP pools information
 relay Miscellaneous DHCP relay information
 snooping DHCP snooping
Switch#

comments.content: wrong. reread the question. you are confusing a lot of people
Wrong, the pool parameter displays the DHCP pool available. The binding parameter lists addresses leased (binding) to clients

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct
"show ip dhcp binding": This will display all the IP addresses allocated by the DHCP server, including the MAC address of the device holding the lease, the lease expiration time, and the type of lease.
If you're checking which IP addresses are currently in use on your network, you would enter "show ip dhcp binding".
Show ip DHCP binding

Selected Answer: C
Router#show ip dhcp binding - Displays a list of all bindings created.

https://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=1574301&seqNum=6
show ip dhcp binding is the right answer
Binding gives you the actual addresses leased. Pool just gives the statistics regarding what is configured and will only tell you the number of addresses leased, not the actual address.
key word "Have been assigned" DHCP binding shows you exactly that

i Think Its B. 
it was stated IP addresses assigned on DHCP server.
If its assigned by DHCP server that could be C.
Answer is correct

In DNS, "authoritative" basically means, who can be trusted to own and know the dns entries for the specified item. In this item, its asking for an authoritative source, which has to be a server. DNS entries that are cached can be wrong, old/outdated. So Caches are ruled out. Now, this is a terrible question, but a basically, a recursive dns query is a packet that goes out to the big work dns networks and "walks the tree" to find an authoritative dns server for the website you are looking for. https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/dns/what-is-recursive-dns/

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A it is!

Helpful article explaining why answer is A:
https://umbrella.cisco.com/blog/what-is-the-difference-between-authoritative-and-recursive-dns-nameservers
Is recursive search an authoritative source?

comments.content: that's tricky, i guess the key is in the word source. The other answer are cached, so they will come from a first DNS lookup and that is the Source.

B,C,D are CACHE from the authoritative server when happens. ISP (DNS server) runs recursive search (root server -> TLD server -> authoritative server) to get correct name resolution and cache the result. Browser requests name solution from ISP and cache the result
